answers.answer: Dear DAC - miss you a bunch hun!!!Here is my deal. Swelling: Yep -- I have that as you know. Ocassionally I get that rig bulge but for about a month I have seen some change. I don't seem to fight as much to sit up straight evvery day any more. I never took any meds for the water retention (which this is what I think it is)The stomach pain I had was there and since I started a daily routine of acidophillus - that has seemed to go away. It also solved my IBS and acid too. and maybe some of the bloating went away with that too. ...... not sure.I think Lithium antidepressants with thyroid meds are the bad ones together. I don't know if benzo's are connected yet with that.WHen I switched from Synthroid to Armour - I noticed better results. I felt energy wise better - The brain fog lifted alot - but I still get it. I lately have been thinking to try Thyrolar instead of Armour. Just to see if I get the altimate results I still am looking for.I was checking on endo disorders coming in three's when we talked- It's amazing on what I read -I this nodule for me didn't come up - I would totally be doing more searches on getting myself balanced.Miss you Dac. We'll connect soon!! :)
Thanks, Stella.  I'm calling today about getting switched to Armour or Thyrolar.

My endo says he doesn;t believe there us a connection to anti-d's and thyroid disease. Obviously- Lithium, but with the SSRI's  he hasn't seen a link. He is a Top Doc and I do trust him.I asked him last week if when I am weaned off Lexapro (which i am currently in the process of) would I need a dose change. He said no. I mentioned that Zoloft is connected with either causing hypo or requiring an increased levo dose. This is when he said he has personally seen no link in his experience.The benzo's are anti-anxiety meds, not antidepressants. I have never seen in the literature a warning about them and levo.Hope some of this is helpful!

There's nothing about the ADs causing thyroid problems.  It says that Levothyroxine--only one listed--is not suppose to be taken with AD's.  I'm on big time amount of Celexa for my depression and also anxiety, but it states that the levo can make the anxiety worse if taken with AD's.Have done a lot of research into this.  The entire lithium/thyroid med issue is a real mess when you read it.  Lithium destroys thyroid tissue, but they don't want you taking the 2 together.  HUH?  Crazy.The swelling. . .it is an expected symptom of being hypo, but not when my levels are really good.  My drs don't even know at this point what is causing it.  There is nothing medically wrong with me to make me swell now.  And I don't eat a lot of salt so that's not it.  Have read lots and lots of stuff now about the swelling being one of the bad side affects of levo.Should have stated this earlier.  They don't think it is the thyroid hormone itself that has the bad side affects.  Levothyroxine has a lot of supposed "inactive" ingredients that they think is the culprit with it.  The others don't have the same ones and it's the most different from all the synthetic thryoid meds.Also have to consider my diabetes and wether or not it was really caused by the levo and if I would do much better on something natural.  That's a big factor in al this.Thanks for the input.  Always appreciate all the help I get on here.Dac

So are you saying that the generic levothyroxine is listed as contraindicated with AD's?I have never heard about the generic being so different, except that it's amount of active ingredient that can vary.I may be off the mark about your swelling with this next tidbit. But, I take magnesium for PMS type fluid retention. I forgot to take it much last month and oh, did I pay for it with bloating. I had to squeeze myself into my jeans- yuck!What is it about levo causing diabetes? Do you have any references? I would like to bring this up with my endo. He thinks I may have Schmidt's Syndrome (PAS, type 2) b/c of autoimmune hypo and possible adrenal insufficiency. PAS-2 often includes diabetes, so I would like to have a heads up about this possibility, especially if I am predisposed to it.Thanks for your info as well.Kitty

Here is a link that might interest you. I picked Synthroid, but if you punch in Levothyroxine, it is almost identical reading. It mentions a warning about levothyroxine (synthroid) and anti-depressants.https://online.epocrates.com/u/10a1266/Synthroid?mode=SingleMatch&src=PKThe specific warning is about halfway down the page, but the other info is worth browsing through as well.

Will try and find it again.  It was a link from something Justin posted that I got it from.I haven't read the one that AR posted yet, so will peruse it and see if it gives the same info.It's the "inactive" ingredients in it that they think are causing all the problems.  Not the "active" ones.  They are basically the same.

question: Wondering if you've had the same side affects that I seem to have.Still have lots of swelling.  Face always looks swollen.  Also have very large bulge under my ribs, have heard others complain about this also.  Have to take Lasix quite regularly for the swelling in entire body.Read where stomach pain is one of the side affects as well.  Also head aches.  Hair loss can continue the entire time taken also.  Still have no energy, but figure it is from everything that is wrong with me, but not sure.Also read that you are not suppose to take levo with antidepressants!  What?  Don't most of us?  Rather freaky.  Also have read reports of it causing diabetes with long-term use.  Yep, I'm right there with that one.  When you do get diabetes it says you will have to increase the anti-diabetic drugs b/c of the levo.Here's my deal.  Fired my endo so I don't have to worry about the fact that she won't prescribe Armour and now I think my PCP probably will when I ask him.  Which I'm going to do at my next appt.If anyone has stories regarding any of this and levo I'd LOVE to hear them.  Also success stories of changing from levo to Armour.Thanks,Dac
